Wary Of NASA Satellites, How Farmers Time Crop-Burning, Scientist Explains

Claim:  A viral video claims farmers in Punjab use NASA satellite images to time crop burning so they can evade detection.

Fact Check:  NDTV spoke to a scientist at the Punjab Remote Sensing Centre who confirmed that farmers do indeed use publicly available NASA satellite imagery to identify cloud cover and atmospheric conditions. This information allows them to burn stubble when conditions are most likely to obscure the smoke, making detection more difficult.

The scientist explained that the centre itself uses satellite data to monitor stubble burning, but the same data is accessible to anyone, including farmers. He further stated that the timing of crop burning often coincides with periods of cloud cover or stable atmospheric conditions that trap pollutants near the ground. This deliberate timing makes the task of accurately identifying and mapping the burning instances from satellite imagery more challenging.
title: The same post went viral earlier on June 2016, following which the  Railways confirmed that no such changes were proposed. A PIB release from 2017 also says that the claims made in the viral post is false.
